docs.title: Chemical Delivery Procedures
docs.text:
This section covers the standard operating procedures for receiving bulk chemical deliveries.

!!! danger "PPE Required" Proper Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) must be worn for all deliveries. If PPE is unavailable, STOP and notify a supervisor immediately.

docs.title: 1. Sodium Hypochlorite (NaClO)
docs.text:
• Tank Level Goal: Stop at 82" (Max 84" / 3600 Gallons).
  • Process:
    1. Place a bucket under the Inlet Valve to catch residuals.
    2. CLOSE the Containment Spill Valve.
    3. Take a sample and test specific gravity.
    4. Connect hose and begin filling.
    5. Monitor tank level closely.
    6. After Delivery: Ensure driver blows out the line with air before disconnecting.
    7. OPEN Containment Spill Valve if no leaks occurred.

docs.title: 2. Hydrated Lime (Ca(OH)₂)
docs.text:
• Target Fill: 2,600 Gallons.
  • Process:
    1. Ensure recirculation pumps are OFF.
    2. Connect delivery hose to the 3" extension.
    3. Verify flow path: Open valves #1, #2, #5; Close #3, #4.
    4. Start delivery. Press RED "STOP" button on VFD when full.
    5. Flush: Open valve #2a, Close #1a to fill second tank if needed.

docs.title: 3. PAC (PCH-180)
docs.text:
• Storage Sides: North (Lime Bin side) vs. South (Window side).
  • Process:
    1. CLOSE Containment Spill Valve.
    2. Collect sample from driver.
    3. Verify receiving tank valves are OPEN and opposite side is CLOSED.
    4. Fill bins one at a time.
    5. Venting: Near end of delivery, open valves on the opposite side to allow air blow-off into the least full bin.
    6. OPEN Containment Spill Valve after completion.

docs.title: Sodium Hypochlorite (NaClO)
docs.text: Sodium Hypochlorite is the primary disinfectant used at the Albany Water Department. It is a clear, light yellow-green liquid with a strong chlorine odor.

docs.title: Chemical Properties
docs.text:
• Trade Name: Hypo, Bleach
  • Strength: Delivered at 15% available chlorine.
  • Specific Gravity: ~1.21 (Heavier than water).
  • pH: > 12 (Highly Alkaline/Caustic).

docs.title: Application Points
docs.text:
Location Purpose Dosage Range Raw Water Pre-oxidation & Algae Control 0.5 - 1.0 mg/L Filtered Water Primary Disinfection 1.5 - 2.5 mg/L Reservoirs Residual Maintenance As Needed

!!! danger "Safety Warning" NEVER mix Sodium Hypochlorite with acids (like fluoride or PAC). This reaction releases Chlorine Gas, which can be fatal.

docs.title: Hydrated Lime (Ca(OH)₂)
docs.text: Hydrated Lime is used for pH adjustment and corrosion control. It creates a protective scale on pipes to prevent lead and copper leaching.

docs.title: Chemical Properties
docs.text:
• Form: White powder (slurry when mixed).
  • pH: 12.4 (Saturated solution).
  • Solubility: Poor. Requires constant mixing to prevent settling.

docs.title: Handling Procedures
docs.text:
• Dust Hazard: Lime dust is a severe respiratory irritant. Always use dust collection systems when loading.
  • Line Clogging: Lime slurries scale pipes quickly. Lines must be flushed with clear water immediately after use.

!!! tip "Operational Tip" If the lime feed pump is air-locked or clogged, check the Anti-Siphon Valve first. It is the most common point of failure.

docs.title: Polyaluminum Chloride (PAC)
docs.text: Trade Name: PCH-180 * Purpose: Coagulant. It neutralizes charges on particles to form floc. * Appearance: Clear to slightly hazy liquid. * Corrosivity: Highly corrosive to metals (aluminum, steel). Use PVC or stainless steel lines only.

docs.title: Sodium Permanganate (NaMnO4)
docs.text:
• Purpose: Taste & Odor control; Iron/Manganese removal.
  • Appearance: Deep purple liquid.
  • Staining: Will permanently stain skin and concrete brown/black.
  • Overdose Sign: If finished water has a pink tint, permanganate is passing through the filters. Reduce dose immediately.

docs.title: Pressure Mechanics
docs.text:
• Gravity Rule: Every 1 foot of water column creates 0.433 psi of pressure.
  • Example: A 100-foot tank creates 43.3 psi at the base ($100 \times 0.433$).

docs.title: Maintenance Checks
docs.text:
• Daily: Check pump discharge pressures and tank levels via SCADA.
  • Annual: Inspect internal/external tank conditions (often contracted out).
  • Water Age: Tanks must be cycled (filled at night, drained during day) to prevent stagnation and loss of chlorine residual.

docs.title: Supply Reservoirs
docs.text: The City of Albany draws water from two primary upland reservoirs located in the Helderberg Mountains.

docs.title: 1. Alcove Reservoir
docs.text:
• Type: Primary Supply.
  • Capacity: ~12 Billion Gallons.
  • Characteristics: High quality, low turbidity water.
  • Intake: Water flows by gravity to the Filtration Plant.

docs.title: 2. Basic Creek Reservoir
docs.text:
• Type: Secondary / Feeder Supply.
  • Function: Flows into Alcove Reservoir via a connecting tunnel.
  • Management: Used to top off Alcove during dry seasons.

!!! note "Watershed Protection" Boating, swimming, and unauthorized fishing are strictly prohibited to maintain raw water quality.

docs.title: Tank & Line Cleaning
docs.text: Procedures for flushing sedimentation basins and cleaning chemical lines.

docs.title: Sedimentation Basin Flush
docs.text:
Frequency: As needed (typically seasonal) or when sludge blanket rises.

  1. Setup:
    • Isolate Basin Effluent valves.
    • Raise plant elevation to ~21 inches.
    • Open influent for the target Waste Lagoon.
  2. Flush:
    • Crack the Drain valve (15-20 turns) to charge the line.
    • Slowly open fully (15-20 turns every 10 mins).
  3. Wash Down:
    • Use plant elevation to backflow water from the filter channel.
    • Use hose streams to clean corners and drain openings.
  4. Restore:
    • Close drain and slowly refill over 48 hours.
    • Note: Refill rate should be ~1 MGD > Outflow.

docs.title: Lime Line Cleaning
docs.text:
Trigger: When rotating to a new tank or if lines clog.

  1. Flush:
    • Hook water line to the empty tank's dosing pump.
    • Close finished system valve; Open flush valve.
    • Run pump at Max Speed to reverse flow and flush lines.
  2. Finish:
    • Flush until water runs clear (approx. 2 mins).
    • Re-connect dosing pump to new tank.

docs.title: Chemical Dosing Checks
docs.text: Automated SCADA readings must be physically verified once per shift to ensure feed pumps are accurate.

docs.title: Verification Procedure (Drawdown Test)
docs.text:
This test confirms the actual mL/min output of a chemical pump.

  1. Isolate: Close the valve from the bulk tank to the calibration column.
  2. Fill: Open the column fill valve to fill the calibration tube.
  3. Run: Let the pump draw from the column for exactly 1 minute.
  4. Measure: Record the mL dropped in the column.
  5. Calculate: $$\text{Feed Rate (GPH)} = \frac{\text{mL/min} \times 0.0158}{1}$$

docs.title: Tank Level Inspections
docs.text:
Check physical tank levels against SCADA.

  • [ ] Sodium Hypochlorite: Verify day tank level matches ultrasonic sensor.
  • [ ] PAC (Polymer): Visually inspect mixing energy in the day tank.
  • [ ] Fluoride: Ensure saturator tank has visible crystals (undissolved salt) at the bottom.

!!! warning "Air Lock" If a pump is running but the flow meter reads zero, the pump head may be air-locked. Follow the Pump Priming SOP.

docs.title: Filter Backwash Procedure
docs.text: Filters must be washed when they reach terminal headloss, turbidity breakthrough, or a run time of 72 hours.

docs.title: Pre-Wash Checklist
docs.text:
• [ ] Ensure Backwash Tank is full (> 20 ft).
  • [ ] Verify Air Scour Blower is available.
  • [ ] Check Waste Gullet gate is clear.

docs.title: Automatic Wash Sequence
docs.text:
Initiate "Auto-Wash" on the SCADA panel. The system will cycle through:

  1. Drain Down: Level drops to 6 inches above media.
  2. Air Scour: Air is injected for 3 minutes to break up the mud ball layer.
  3. Low Wash: Water enters at 2,000 gpm to fluidize the bed.
  4. High Wash: Flow increases to 8,000 gpm to flush solids to the trough.
  5. Settle: 2-minute pause to let media stratify (sand on bottom, coal on top).

docs.title: Post-Wash Validation
docs.text: After the filter returns to service: * Monitor: Watch the turbidity meter for the first 15 minutes. * Filter-to-Waste: Ensure the valve closes only after turbidity drops below 0.20 NTU.

docs.title: Water Quality Analysis (Daily)
docs.text: Daily lab analysis is the primary method for validating plant performance and regulatory compliance.

docs.title: Routine Bench Tests
docs.text:
Operators must perform the following bench tests every 4 hours.

Parameter Target Range Critical Limit Method pH (Raw) 6.8 - 7.2 N/A Electrometric pH (Finished) 8.0 - 8.5 < 7.5 Electrometric Chlorine (Free) 1.8 - 2.2 mg/L < 1.5 mg/L DPD Colorimetric Turbidity (Clearwell) < 0.10 NTU > 0.30 NTU Nephelometric Fluoride 0.6 - 0.8 mg/L > 2.0 mg/L SPADNS

docs.title: Sampling Locations
docs.text:
1. Raw Water: Sample tap located on the incoming 48" line (Pre-Aeration).
  2. Settled Water: Sample from the flume exiting the sedimentation basins.
  3. Entry Point (EP): Finished water tap in the lab (Representing water entering distribution).

!!! danger "Critical Violation" If Entry Point Free Chlorine drops below 0.2 mg/L, you must immediately notify the Chief Operator and start the Low Chlorine Emergency Protocol.

docs.title: Aeration Process
docs.text: Aeration is often the first major process at the treatment plant. It brings water and air into close contact to remove dissolved gases and oxidize dissolved metals.

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
Aeration works by exposing drops or thin sheets of water to the air, or by introducing small air bubbles.

  • Scrubbing: Turbulence physically removes dissolved gases from the solution, allowing them to escape into the air.
  • Oxidation: Oxygen combines with undesirable metals. Once oxidized, these chemicals fall out of solution and become particles that can be removed by filtration.

!!! tip "Efficiency Factors" The efficiency of aeration depends on the amount of surface contact between air and water. This is controlled primarily by the size of the water drop or air bubble.

docs.title: Impact on Water Quality
docs.text:
• Taste: Increases palpability by removing the "flat" taste.
  • Temperature: Cold water can hold more oxygen than warm water.
  • Corrosion Warning: Excessive oxygen can make water corrosive or cause "air binding" in filters.

docs.title: Chemicals Removed or Oxidized
docs.text:
Aeration effectively targets the following constituents:

  • Volatile Organic Chemicals (VOCs): Including benzene, trichloroethylene, and others found in industrial processes.
  • Dissolved Gases: Carbon dioxide, Hydrogen sulfide (Rotten egg odor), Methane.
  • Metals: Iron and Manganese.
  • Other: Ammonia and Chlorine.

docs.title: Coagulation, Flocculation & Sedimentation
docs.text: Once raw water enters the plant, the first major treatment phase is Clarification. The goal is to remove suspended solids by clumping them together so they settle out.

docs.title: 1. Coagulation (The Chemical Mix)
docs.text:
• What it is: The addition of a chemical coagulant to neutralize the electrical charge of suspended particles.
  • Chemical Used: Polyaluminum Chloride (PAC) (also known as PCH-180).
  • Process:
    • Raw water particles are generally negatively charged.
    • PAC (positively charged) is added in the Rapid Mix zone.
    • This destabilizes the particles, allowing them to stick together.

docs.title: 2. Flocculation (The Slow Mix)
docs.text:
• Duration: Approximately 20 minutes.
  • Process:
    • Water enters the Mixing Basin.
    • Gentle mixing causes the neutralized particles to collide and clump into larger, heavier masses called "Floc".
    • Operator Check: You should be able to visually see floc forming in the basin. If water looks cloudy without distinct clumps, the process may be failing.

docs.title: 3. Sedimentation (The Settling)
docs.text:
• Duration: Approximately 2 hours.
  • Capacity: Each basin holds ~1.5 Million Gallons.
  • Process:
    • Water flows slowly through the Settling Basins.
    • The heavy "Floc" settles to the bottom (forming sludge).
    • The clean, clarified water rises to the top and flows over the weirs into the Filtration Flume.
    • Maintenance: Sludge must be periodically flushed to the Waste Lagoons to prevent it from becoming septic or carrying over into the filters.

docs.title: Disinfection
docs.text: Disinfection is the process used to inactivate (destroy) harmful microorganisms. While filtration removes particles, disinfection targets bacteria and viruses.

docs.title: Disinfection Strategy
docs.text:
We use a multi-barrier approach involving different chemicals at different stages.

Chemical Formula Usage Stage Purpose Sodium Permanganate NaMnO4 Raw Water Intake Taste/Odor control & Pre-oxidation Sodium Hypochlorite NaClO Pre-Filtration Aids filtration & reduces algae growth in basins Sodium Hypochlorite NaClO Post-Filtration Primary disinfection to kill bacteria (E. coli)

docs.title: Key Concepts
docs.text:
• Primary Disinfection: Occurs in the Clearwell (Pure Well). The water must be held here long enough (Contact Time) for the chlorine to effectively kill pathogens before leaving the plant.
  • Residual: We must maintain a chlorine residual throughout the distribution system to prevent bacterial regrowth in the pipes.

docs.title: pH Adjustment
docs.text: Immediately after disinfection, Hydrated Lime ($Ca(OH)_2$) is added. * Goal: To raise the pH and alkalinity. * Reason: To make the water non-corrosive so it does not damage distribution pipes or leach lead from household plumbing.

docs.title: Filtration Process
docs.text: Following clarification, the water enters the Filtration stage. This marks the shift from chemical treatment to physical removal of particles.

docs.title: Filter Design
docs.text:
The plant utilizes Rapid Sand Filters constructed of reinforced concrete (approx. 34' x 50'). Each filter acts as a physical barrier to remove remaining suspended solids and pathogens (like Giardia and Cryptosporidium).

Layer Material Function Top Layer Anthracite Coal Traps larger floc particles Bottom Layer Sand Polishes water by trapping fine particles Support Gravel Supports media and distributes backwash water

docs.title: Operational Standards
docs.text:
• Capacity: Each filter can process up to 4 Million Gallons Per Day (MGD).
  • Turbidity Goal: Must be $\le 0.3$ NTU in 95% of samples.
  • Absolute Limit: Turbidity must never exceed 1 NTU.

docs.title: The Backwash Cycle
docs.text:
When filter media becomes clogged with trapped solids, efficiency drops and the filter must be cleaned.

  1. Backwash: Clean water and air (scour) are forced backward through the filter to lift the bed and scrub the media.
  2. Filter-to-Waste: Before returning to service, the filter runs to waste for a short period. This allows the media to settle and ensures no loose particles pass into the clearwell.

!!! warning "Turbidity Spike" Rules allow for a temporary increase in turbidity for 4 hours immediately following a backwash, as the filter "seasons" itself.

docs.title: Water Treatment Overview
docs.text: Qualified, dedicated, and capable water treatment plant operators are responsible for providing potable, palatable water to the public 24 hours each day and 365 days each year. To do so requires operators to understand basic conventional treatment processes that are key to ensuring drinking water quality and preventing waterborne disease.

docs.title: Raw Water
docs.text:
Before treatment, water taken from the ground or from a surface source is called Raw Water.

Water characteristics differ from one source to another. Each aquifer or surface source has water of a different quality and chemical profile that will determine what type of treatment it should receive.

docs.title: Groundwater
docs.text: Groundwater is raw water that’s taken from wells. * Characteristics: Usually clear enough and clean enough that the only treatment needed may be to just add a chlorine disinfectant. * Requirements: All water, regardless of its origin, requires disinfection before entering the distribution system. * Additional Treatment: At times, groundwater may need treatment to address undesirable aesthetics (tastes, odors, or color).

docs.title: Surface Water
docs.text:
Surface water can come from lakes, rivers, reservoirs, or the ocean. Depending on the source, the water’s characteristics will determine the necessary treatment.

  • Low pH Waters: May require pH adjustment at the treatment plant.
  • High Salinity: May require advanced membrane treatment to remove salt.
  • Minimum Requirement: At the very least, raw surface water will need treatment to remove solids, followed by some form of filtration and chemical disinfection.

docs.title: Water Treatment Categories
docs.text: Water Treatment involves any process in which a source water’s quality is improved for drinking, irrigation, industrial uses, and many other applications.

docs.title: 1. Conventional Treatment
docs.text: These are traditional, time-tested physical and chemical processes used to improve water quality from source to tap. * Goal: To protect public health, these processes remove various drinking water contaminants in accordance with the US EPA National Primary Drinking Water Regulations. * Operator Role: Operators must manage, maintain, and repair facilities. Performing these duties successfully requires good judgment and an understanding of the fundamentals.

docs.title: 2. Advanced Treatment
docs.text: It is becoming vital for operators to understand advanced treatment processes, as many utilities are starting to use newer technologies (such as membranes) to address specific water quality challenges.

docs.title: Storage & Distribution
docs.text: The distribution system consists of all pipes, valves, pumping stations, and storage facilities that convey water to the customer.

docs.title: Water Storage Tanks
docs.text: Storage tanks serve three critical functions: 1. Equalization: Allows the plant to run at a steady flow rate while demand fluctuates. 2. Emergency Supply: Provides reserve water for firefighting or power outages. 3. Pressure: Elevated tanks create pressure via gravity.

docs.title: Managing "Water Age"
docs.text: Operators must cycle tanks (fill them up and drain them down) to keep water fresh. * Stagnation Risk: If water sits too long, chlorine residual drops, leading to potential biofilm growth or nitrification. * Routine: Typically, tanks are filled at night (low demand) and drained during the day (high demand).

• Corrosion Control: We maintain a slight scale-forming water chemistry to coat pipes and prevent rust.
